column1: Morondava [murunˈdav̥] is a city located in Menabe Region
column2: of which it is the capital
column3: in Madagascar. It is located in the delta of the Morandava River at 20°17′5″S 44°19′3″E.

column1: Air Madagascar has regular scheduled flights to Morondava Airport. The main road to town has been renovated recently. With the new road established
column2: a trip from Antananarivo to Morondava by taxi-brousse takes approximately 12 hours. Pirogues are consequently a popular mode of transport used to ferry people and goods along the coast

column1: The city is famous amongst other things for the spectacular Avenue of Baobabs nearby at 20.251000°S 44.418403°E﻿ / -20.251000; 44.418403﻿ (Avenue of Baobabs). These giant baobab trees are an 800-year-old legacy of the dense tropical forests that once throve here. Over the years
column3: the forests were steadily cut down
column5: which the locals preserved for religious reasons. Today
column6: deforestation still continues as large areas of this region
column7: including some of few remaining baobabs
column8: are cleared to make way for sugar cane plantations.

column1: The Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve
column3: is located 150 km north of Morondava. The road from Morondava is poor
column4: but Tsingy de Bemaraha is reachable by 4x4 in approximately 10 hours.

column1: In the South there is the Andranomena Reserve.

Kirindy Forest at 20.070000°S 44.601944°E﻿ / -20.070000; 44.601944﻿ (Kirindy Forest) is a nature reserve about 60 km from Morondava where many of the local species of lemurs as well as other plants and animals can be spotted during a day or night trip.
